Award.AwardTitle: Novel Magnetic Shape Memory Alloy Thin Films for Sensor and Actuator Applications

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to investigate novel magnetic shape memory alloy thin films and use these films as the backbone of sensors and actuators. In particular, a class of novel Ni-based Heusler alloy films, which is capable of delivering high frequency response as well as high actuation strain due to Zeeman energy induced phase transformations, will be used as a model system and tested for real applications. This objective will be achieved by using the following scientific approaches: (1) investigate the influence of phase segregation on phase transformations; (2) explore and tailor residual stress in films to tune phase transformations; (3) understand the size effect on field induced strain and reversible phase transformations; (4) demonstrate the concept of magnetic field sensing via bilayer films; and (5) fabricate actuators via membranes.

If successful, the benefits of this research will include elucidation of fundamental magneto-microstructural mechanisms of field-induced shape change across multiple length scales, and a new class of magnetic shape memory alloy films for sensor and actuator applications. The project will significantly improve the design of active sensing systems capable of fast and reversible deformation, damping and passive power generation. Second, it will promote a local learning environment focusing on magnetic thin films. Activities will include creation of teaching modules of active materials, involvement of underrepresented groups through the ?Pathway to Ph.D.? fellowship program at Texas A&M University, laboratory demonstration models in nanomaterials for grades 7-12, and involvement of undergraduate researchers. Third, collaborations with scientists at the Center for Integrated Nanotechnologies, at Los Alamos National Laboratory and Sandia National Laboratory through the existing user project will provide graduate student opportunities to work at these advanced research centers and laboratories.

ProgramReference.Text: SENSORS AND SENSOR SYSTEMS FOR CIS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project outcome report - NSF-CMMI 112905

Title: Novel Magnetic Shape Memory Alloy Thin Films for Sensor and Actuator Applications

 

This project targets novel magnetic shape memory alloy thin films, a class of Heusler alloy films-NiCoMnIn and NiCoMnAl in particular, which are capable of delivering high actuation strain due to Zeeman energy induced phase transformations and can be used as model system and tested for real applications. Magnetic shape memory alloys (MSMAs) combine the large strain output of conventional SMAs with the high frequency response of magnetostrictive materials in bulk forms. To utilize these materials in smaller volumes such as MEMS/NEMS device, sensors and actuators, they have to be in the form of thin films. However, the effects of phase segregation, stress and length scale effect on phase transformations in these films are far from clear. Furthermore there are little studies on the application of NiCoMnIn (Al) films for sensor and actuator applications to date.

Intellectual merit. The major scientific findings of this project can be briefly summarized as follows. First, we deposited NiCoMnAl thin films by magnetron sputtering. Heat treatment of films led to a B2 austenite phase, which exhibited a magnetic field induced martensitic phase transformation temperature to the extent of 2 K/Tesla. This is the first time that NiCoMnAl films have been shown to have such field induced phase transformation. Furthermore we show that appropriate heat treatment can tailor grain growth and consequently an increase in martensitic phase transformation temperatures, revealing a prominent grain size effect on martensitic phase transformation. Second, we investigated Ni50Co6Mn38In6 films. Our studies show that cobalt-rich precipitates induced by heat treatment decrease the valence electron concentration (e/a) of the twinned martensite, and hence cause a decrease in martensitic phase transformation temperature. We have also modeled the grain size dependent martensite transformations validated the prediction in several MSMA systems. Third, Two-stage stress induced martensitic phase transformation,  a widely observed phenomenon in MSMA alloys, is described conventionally as a first stage L21 (austenite)-to-10M/14M (M: modulated martensite) transition, followed by a second stage 14M-to-L10 (tetragonal martensite) transformation at higher stresses. Here we show, for the first time via in-situ nanoindentation on single crystalline Ni54Fe19Ga27 alloy, that a reversible L21-to-10M/14M transformation took place at lower stress. However at higher stress, an irreversible transition from residual L21 to L10 martensite (a 2nd type of phase transformation) occurred. Furthermore phase fronts propagate gradually during the L21-to-10M/14M transformation, whereas L10 is abruptly emitted in a jerky style during the 14M-to-L10 transformation. Detailed examination of crystal structure suggests that a direct transition from 14M to observed L10 is crystallographically forbidden in the current loading condition. This study provides new perspective for understanding of stress induced various types of phase transformations in MSMAs.

  Broader impact. (a) Outreach to scientific community. During this project, we collaborated with scientists from Los Alamos National Laboratory and graduate student visited Los Alamos in summer for research. (b) Dissemination of results to broader audience. The PI’s team has hosted numerous undergraduate students and high...

However, the effects of phase segregation, stress and length scale effect on phase transformations in these films are far from clear. Furthermore there are little studies on the application of NiCoMnIn (Al) films for sensor and actuator applications to date. Intellectual merit. However at higher stress, an irreversible transition from residual L21 to L10 martensite (a 2nd type of phase transformation) occurred. Furthermore phase fronts propagate gradually during the L21-to-10M/14M transformation, whereas L10 is abruptly emitted in a jerky style during the 14M-to-L10 transformation. Detailed examination of crystal structure suggests that a direct transition from 14M to observed L10 is crystallographically forbidden in the current loading condition. This study provides new perspective for understanding of stress induced various types of phase transformations in MSMAs. Broader impact. (a) Outreach to scientific community. During this project, we collaborated with scientists from Los Alamos National Laboratory and graduate student visited Los Alamos in summer for research. (b) Dissemination of results to broader audience. The PIÆs team has hosted numerous undergraduate students and high school teachers in consecutive years and involved them in this project. (c) Professional preparation for students. 2 Ph.D. students were directly involved in this project. One of them has become a postdoc at Los Alamos National Laboratory. Another Ph.D. student is now senior project manager at company in Texas. 1 female Hispanic undergrad has become a community colleague teacher. (d) Award and recognition. 1 Ph.D. student was awarded the prestigious Thesis Fellowship by Texas A&M Universit...
